text: "That's right," K.would say, although it was clear that the investigating committee wasnot to be found there, and so his task was at an end.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There were manywho thought it must be very important for K. to find Lanz the joiner andthought long about it, naming a joiner who was not called Lanz or givinga name that had some vague similarity with Lanz, or they askedneighbours or accompanied K. to a door a long way away where theythought someone of that sort might live in the back part of the buildingor where someone would be who could advise K. better than they couldthemselves.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. eventually had to give up asking if he did not want tobe led all round from floor to floor in this way.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He regretted hisinitial plan, which had at first seemed so practical to him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As hereached the fifth floor, he decided to give up the search, took hisleave of a friendly, young worker who wanted to lead him on stillfurther and went down the stairs.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But then the thought of how much timehe was wasting made him cross, he went back again and knocked at thefirst door on the fifth floor.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The first thing he saw in the small roomwas a large clock on the wall which already showed ten o'clock.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Isthere a joiner called Lanz who lives here?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: he asked.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Pardon?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: said ayoung woman with black, shining eyes who was, at that moment, washingchildren's underclothes in a bucket.
author: Franz Kafka

text: She pointed her wet hand towardsthe open door of the adjoining room.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. thought he had stepped into a meeting.
author: Franz Kafka

text: A medium sized, twowindowed room was filled with the most diverse crowd of people - nobodypaid any attention to the person who had just entered.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Close under itsceiling it was surrounded by a gallery which was also fully occupied andwhere the people could only stand bent down with their heads and theirbacks touching the ceiling.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K., who found the air too stuffy, steppedout again and said to the young woman, who had probably misunderstoodwhat he had said, "I asked for a joiner, someone by the name of Lanz.
author: Franz Kafka

text: ""Yes," said the woman, "please go on in."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. would probably not havefollowed her if the woman had not gone up to him, taken hold of the doorhandle and said, "I'll have to close the door after you, no-one elsewill be allowed in."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Very sensible," said K., "but it's too fullalready."
author: Franz Kafka

text: But then he went back in anyway.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He passed through betweentwo men who were talking beside the door - one of them held both handsfar out in front of himself making the movements of counting out money,the other looked him closely in the eyes - and someone took him by thehand.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was a small, red-faced youth.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Come in, come in," he said.K.
author: Franz Kafka

text: let himself be led by him, and it turned out that there was -surprisingly in a densely packed crowd of people moving to and fro - anarrow passage which may have been the division between two factions;this idea was reinforced by the fact that in the first few rows to theleft and the right of him there was hardly any face looking in hisdirection, he saw nothing but the backs of people directing their speechand their movements only towards members of their own side.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Most ofthem were dressed in black, in old, long, formal frock coats that hungdown loosely around them.
author: Franz Kafka

text: These clothes were the only thing thatpuzzled  K., as he would otherwise have taken the whole assembly for alocal political meeting.
author: Franz Kafka

text: At the other end of the hall where K. had been led there was alittle table set at an angle on a very low podium which was asovercrowded as everywhere else, and behind the table, near the edge ofthe podium, sat a small, fat, wheezing man who was talking with someonebehind him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This second man was standing with his legs crossed and hiselbows on the backrest of the chair, provoking much laughter.
author: Franz Kafka

text: From timeto time he threw his arm in the air as if doing a caricature of someone.The youth who was leading K. had some difficulty in reporting to theman.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He had already tried twice to tell him something, standing on tip-toe, but without getting the man's attention as he sat there above him.It was only when one of the people up on the podium drew his attentionto the youth that the man turned to him and leant down to hear what itwas he quietly said.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Then he pulled out his watch and quickly lookedover at K.  "You should have been here one hour and five minutes ago,"he said.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. was going to give him a reply but had no time to do so, ashardly had the man spoken than a general muttering arose all over theright hand side of the hall.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "You should have been here one hour andfive minutes ago," the man now repeated, raising his voice this time,and quickly looked round the hall beneath him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The muttering alsobecame immediately louder and, as the man said nothing more, died awayonly gradually.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Now the hall was much quieter than when K. had entered.Only the people up in the gallery had not stopped passing remarks.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Asfar as could be distinguished, up in the half-darkness, dust and haze,they seemed to be less well dressed than those below.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Many of them hadbrought pillows that they had put between their heads and the ceiling sothat they would not hurt themselves pressed against it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. had decided he would do more watching than talking, so he didnot defend himself for supposedly having come late, and simply said,"Well maybe I have arrived late, I'm here now."
author: Franz Kafka

text: There followed loudapplause, once more from the right hand side of the hall.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Easy peopleto get on your side, thought K., and was bothered only by the quiet fromthe left hand side which was directly behind him and from which therewas applause from only a few individuals.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He wondered what he could sayto get all of them to support him together or, if that were notpossible, to at least get the support of the others for a while.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Yes," said the man, "but I'm now no longer under any obligationto hear your case" - there was once more a muttering, but this time itwas misleading as the man waved the people's objections aside with hishand and continued - "I will, however, as an exception, continue with ittoday.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But you should never arrive late like this again.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And now, stepforward!"
author: Franz Kafka

text: Someone jumped down from the podium so that there would be aplace free for K., and K. stepped up onto it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He stood pressed closelyagainst the table, the press of the crowd behind him was so great thathe had to press back against it if he did not want to push the judge'sdesk down off the podium and perhaps the judge along with it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The judge, however, paid no attention to that but sat verycomfortably on his chair and, after saying a few words to close hisdiscussion with the man behind him, reached for a little note book, theonly item on his desk.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was like an old school exercise book and hadbecome quite misshapen from much thumbing.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Now then," said the judge,thumbing through the book.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He turned to K. with the tone of someone whoknows his facts and said, "you are a house painter?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: "No," said K., "Iam the chief clerk in a large bank."
author: Franz Kafka

text: This reply was followed bylaughter among the right hand faction down in the hall, it was so heartythat K. couldn't stop himself joining in with it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The people supportedthemselves with their hands on their knees and shook as if suffering aserious attack of coughing.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Even some of those in the gallery werelaughing.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The judge had become quite cross but seemed to have no powerover those below him in the hall, he tried to reduce what harm had beendone in the gallery and jumped up threatening them, his eyebrows, untilthen hardly remarkable, pushed themselves up and became big, black andbushy over his eyes.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The left hand side of the hall was still quiet, though, the peoplestood there in rows with their faces looking towards the podiumlistening to what was being said there, they observed the noise from theother side of the hall with the same quietness and even allowed someindividuals from their own ranks, here and there, to go forward into theother faction.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The people in the left faction were not only fewer innumber than the right but probably were no more important than them,although their behaviour was calmer and that made it seem like theywere.
author: Franz Kafka

text: When K. now began to speak he was convinced he was doing it inthe same way as them.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Your question, My Lord, as to whether I am a house painter - infact even more than that, you did not ask at all but merely imposed iton me - is symptomatic of the whole way these proceedings against me arebeing carried out.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Perhaps you will object that there are noproceedings against me.
author: Franz Kafka

text: You will be quite right, as there areproceedings only if I acknowledge that there are.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But, for the moment,I do acknowledge it, out of pity for yourselves to a large extent.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It'simpossible not to observe all this business without feeling pity.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Idon't say things are being done without due care but I would like tomake it clear that it is I who make the acknowledgement."K.
author: Franz Kafka

text: stopped speaking and looked down into the hall.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He had spokensharply, more sharply than he had intended, but he had been quite right.It should have been rewarded with some applause here and there buteverything was quiet, they were all clearly waiting for what wouldfollow, perhaps the quietness was laying the ground for an outbreak ofactivity that would bring this whole affair to an end.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was somewhatdisturbing that just then the door at the end of the hall opened, theyoung washerwoman, who seemed to have finished her work, came in and,despite all her caution, attracted the attention of some of the peoplethere.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was only the judge who gave K. any direct pleasure, as heseemed to have been immediately struck by K.'s words.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Until then, hehad listened to him standing, as K.'s speech had taken him by surprisewhile he was directing his attention to the gallery.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Now, in the pause,he sat down very slowly, as if he did not want anyone to notice.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Hetook out the notebook again, probably so that he could give theimpression of being calmer.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "That won't help you, sir," continued K., "even your little bookwill only confirm what I say."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. was satisfied to hear nothing but hisown quiet words in this room full of strangers, and he even daredcasually to pick up the examining judge's notebook and, touching it onlywith the tips of his fingers as if it were something revolting, liftedit in the air, holding it just by one of the middle pages so that theothers on each side of it, closely written, blotted and yellowing,flapped down.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Those are the official notes of the examining judge," hesaid, and let the notebook fall down onto the desk.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "You can read inyour book as much as you like, sir, I really don't have anything in thischarge book to be afraid of, even though I don't have access to it as Iwouldn't want it in my hand, I can only touch it with two fingers."
author: Franz Kafka

text: Thejudge grabbed the notebook from where it had fallen on the desk - whichcould only have been a sign of his deep humiliation, or at least that ishow it must have been perceived - tried to tidy it up a little, and heldit once more in front of himself in order to read from it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The people in the front row looked up at him, showing such tensionon their faces that he looked back down at them for some time.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Everyone of them was an old man, some of them with white beards.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Could theyperhaps be the crucial group who could turn the whole assembly one wayor the other?
author: Franz Kafka

text: They had sunk into a state of  motionlessness while K.gave his oration, and it had not been possible to raise them from thispassivity even when the judge was being humiliated.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "What has happenedto me," continued K., with less of the vigour he had had earlier, hecontinually scanned the faces in the first row, and this gave hisaddress a somewhat nervous and distracted character, "what has happenedto me is not just an isolated case.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If it were it would not be of muchimportance as it's not of much importance to me, but it is a symptom ofproceedings which are carried out against many.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It's on behalf of themthat I stand here now, not for myself alone."
author: Franz Kafka

text: Without having intended it, he had raised his voice.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Somewhere inthe hall, someone raised his hands and applauded him shouting, "Bravo!Why not then?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Bravo!
author: Franz Kafka

text: Again I say, Bravo!"
author: Franz Kafka

text: Some of the men in thefirst row groped around in their beards, none of them looked round tosee who was shouting.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Not even K. thought him of any importance but itdid raise his spirits; he no longer thought it at all necessary that allof those in the hall should applaud him, it was enough if the majorityof them began  to think about the matter and if only one of them, nowand then, was persuaded.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I'm not trying to be a successful orator," said K. after thisthought, "that's probably more than I'm capable of anyway.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I'm sure theexamining judge can speak far better than I can, it is part of his jobafter all.
author: Franz Kafka

text: All that I want is a public discussion of a public wrong.Listen: ten days ago I was placed under arrest, the arrest itself issomething I laugh about but that's beside the point.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They came for mein the morning when I was still in bed.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Maybe the order had been givento arrest some house painter - that seems possible after what the judgehas said - someone who is as innocent as I am, but it was me they chose.There were two police thugs occupying the next room.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They could nothave taken better precautions if I had been a dangerous robber.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Andthese policemen were unprincipled riff-raff, they talked at me till Iwas sick of it, they wanted bribes, they wanted to trick me into givingthem my clothes, they wanted money, supposedly so that they could bringme my breakfast after they had blatantly eaten my own breakfast in frontof my eyes.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And even that was not enough.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I was led in front of thesupervisor in another room.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This was the room of a lady who I have alot of respect for, and I was forced to look on while the supervisor andthe policemen made quite a mess of this room because of me, although notthrough any fault of mine.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was not easy to stay calm, but I managedto do so and was completely calm when I asked the supervisor why it wasthat I was under arrest.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If he were here he would have to confirm whatI say.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I can see him now, sitting on the chair belonging to that lady Imentioned - a picture of dull-witted arrogance.
author: Franz Kafka

text: What do you think heanswered?
author: Franz Kafka

text: What he told me, gentlemen, was basically nothing at all;perhaps he really did know nothing, he had placed me under arrest andwas satisfied.
author: Franz Kafka

text: In fact he had done more than that and brought threejunior employees from the bank where I work into the lady's room; theyhad made themselves busy interfering with some photographs that belongedto the lady and causing a mess.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There was, of course, another reasonfor bringing these employees; they, just like my landlady and her maid,were expected to spread the news of my arrest and damage my publicreputation and in particular to remove me from my position at the bank.Well they didn't succeed in any of that, not in the slightest, even mylandlady, who is quite a simple person - and I will give you here hername in full respect, her name is Mrs. Grubach - even Mrs. Grubach wasunderstanding enough to see that an arrest like this has no moresignificance than an attack carried out on the street by some youths whoare not kept under proper control.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I repeat, this whole affair hascaused me nothing but unpleasantness and temporary irritation, but couldit not also have had some far worse consequences?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. broke off here and looked at the judge, who said nothing.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Ashe did so he thought he saw the judge use a movement of his eyes to givea sign to someone in the crowd.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. smiled and said, "And now the judge,right next to me, is giving a secret sign to someone among you.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Thereseems to be someone among you who is taking directions from above.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Idon't know whether the sign is meant to produce booing or applause, butI'll resist trying to guess what its meaning is too soon.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It reallydoesn't matter to me, and I give his lordship the judge my full andpublic permission to stop giving secret signs to his paid subordinatedown there and give his orders in words instead; let him just say "Boonow!," and then the next time "Clap now!".
author: Franz Kafka

text: Whether it was embarrassment or impatience, the judge rockedbackwards and forwards on his seat.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The man behind him, whom he hadbeen talking with earlier, leant forward again, either to give him a fewgeneral words of encouragement or some specific piece of advice.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Belowthem in the hall the people talked to each other quietly but animatedly.The two factions  had earlier seemed to hold views strongly opposed toeach other but now they began to intermingle, a few individuals pointedup at K., others pointed at the judge.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The air in the room was fuggyand extremely oppressive, those who were standing furthest away couldhardly even be seen through it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It must have been especiallytroublesome for those visitors who were in the gallery, as they wereforced to quietly ask the participants in the assembly what exactly washappening, albeit with timid glances at the judge.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The replies theyreceived were just as quiet, and given behind the protection of a raisedhand.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I have nearly finished what I have to say," said K., and as therewas no bell available he struck the desk with his fist in a way thatstartled the judge and his advisor and made them look up from eachother.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "None of this concerns me, and I am therefore able to make a calmassessment of it, and, assuming that this so-called court is of any realimportance, it will be very much to your advantage to listen to what Ihave to say.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If you want to discuss what I say, please don't bother towrite it down until later on, I don't have any time to waste and I'llsoon be leaving."
author: Franz Kafka

text: There was immediate silence, which showed how well K. was incontrol of the crowd.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There were no shouts among them as there had beenat the start, no-one even applauded, but if they weren't alreadypersuaded they seemed very close to it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K was pleased at the tension among all the people there as theylistened to him, a rustling rose from the silence which was moreinvigorating than the most ecstatic applause could have been.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "There isno doubt," he said quietly, "that there is some enormous organisationdetermining what is said by this court.
author: Franz Kafka

text: In my case this includes myarrest and the examination taking place here today, an organisation thatemploys policemen who can be bribed, oafish supervisors and judges ofwhom nothing better can be said than that they are not as arrogant assome others.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This organisation even maintains a high-level judiciaryalong with its train of countless servants, scribes, policemen and allthe other assistance that  it needs, perhaps even executioners andtorturers - I'm not afraid of using those words.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And what, gentlemen, isthe purpose of this enormous organisation?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Its purpose is to arrestinnocent people and wage pointless prosecutions against them which, asin my case, lead to no result.
author: Franz Kafka

text: How are we to avoid those in officebecoming deeply corrupt when everything is devoid of meaning?
author: Franz Kafka

text: That isimpossible, not even the highest judge would be able to achieve that forhimself.
author: Franz Kafka

text: That is why policemen try to steal the clothes off the back ofthose they arrest, that is why supervisors break into the homes ofpeople they do not know, that is why innocent people are humiliated infront of crowds rather than being given a proper trial.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The policemenonly talked about the warehouses where they put the property of thosethey arrest, I would like to see these warehouses where the hard wonpossessions of people under arrest is left to decay, if, that is, it'snot stolen by the thieving hands of the warehouse workers."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. was interrupted by a screeching from the far end of the hall,he shaded his eyes to see that far, as the dull light of day made thesmoke whitish and hard to see through.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was the washerwoman whom K.had recognised as a likely source of disturbance as soon as she hadentered.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was hard to see now whether it was her fault or not.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K.could only see that a man had pulled her into a corner by the door andwas pressing himself against her.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But it was not her who was screaming,but the man, he had opened his mouth wide and looked up at the ceiling.A small circle had formed around the two of them, the visitors near himin the gallery seemed delighted that the serious tone K. had introducedinto the gathering had been disturbed in this way.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K.'s first thoughtwas to run over there, and he also thought that everyone would want tobring things back into order there or at least to make the pair leavethe room, but the first row of people in front of him stayed were theywere, no-one moved and no-one let K. through.
author: Franz Kafka

text: On the contrary, theystood in his way, old men held out their arms in front of him and a handfrom somewhere - he did not have the time to turn round - took hold ofhis collar.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K., by this time, had forgotten about the pair, it seemedto him that his freedom was being limited as if his arrest was beingtaken seriously, and, without any thought for what he was doing, hejumped down from the podium.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Now he stood face to face with the crowd.Had he judged the people properly?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Had he put too much faith in theeffect of his speech?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Had they been putting up a pretence all the timehe had been speaking, and now that he come to the end and to what mustfollow, were they tired of pretending?
author: Franz Kafka

text: What faces they were, all aroundhim!
author: Franz Kafka

text: Dark, little eyes flickered here and there, cheeks drooped downlike on drunken men, their long beards were thin and stiff, if they tookhold of them it was more like they were making their hands into claws,not as if they were taking hold of their own beards.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But underneaththose beards - and this was the real discovery made by K. - there werebadges of various sizes and colours shining on the collars of theircoats.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As far as he could see, every one of them was wearing one ofthese badges.
author: Franz Kafka

text: All of them belonged to the same group, even though theyseemed to be divided to the right and the left of him, and when hesuddenly turned round he saw the same badge on the collar of theexamining judge who calmly looked down at him with his hands in his lap.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "So," called out K, throwing his arms in the air as if this suddenrealisation needed more room, "all of you are working for thisorganisation, I see now that you are all the very bunch of cheats andliars I've just been speaking about, you've all pressed yourselves inhere in order to listen in and snoop on me, you gave the impression ofhaving formed into factions, one of you even applauded me to test meout, and you wanted to learn how to trap an innocent man!
author: Franz Kafka

text: Well, I hopeyou haven't come here for nothing, I hope you've either had some funfrom someone who expected you to defend his innocence or else - let goof me or I'll hit you," shouted K. to a quivery old man who had pressedhimself especially close to him - "or else that you've actually learnedsomething.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And so I wish you good luck in your trade."
author: Franz Kafka

text: He briskly tookhis hat from where it lay on the edge of the table and, surrounded by asilence caused perhaps by the completeness of their surprise, pushed hisway to the exit.
author: Franz Kafka

text: However, the examining judge seems to have moved evenmore quickly than K., as he was waiting for him at the doorway.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Onemoment," he said.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. stood where he was, but looked at the door withhis hand already on its handle rather than at the judge.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I merelywanted to draw your attention," said the judge, "to something you seemnot yet to be aware of: today, you have robbed yourself of theadvantages that a hearing of this sort always gives to someone who isunder arrest."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. laughed towards the door.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "You bunch of louts," hecalled, "you can keep all your hearings as a present from me," thenopened the door and hurried down the steps.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Behind him, the noise ofthe assembly rose as it became lively once more and probably began todiscuss these events as if making a scientific study of them.Chapter Three In the empty Courtroom - The Student - The Offices        Every day over the following week, K. expected another summons toarrive, he could not believe that his rejection of any more hearings hadbeen taken literally, and when the expected summons really had not comeby Saturday evening he took it to mean that he was expected, withoutbeing told, to appear at the same place at the same time.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So on Sunday,he set out once more in the same direction, going without hesitation upthe steps and through the corridors; some of the people remembered himand greeted him from their doorways, but he no longer needed to askanyone the way and soon arrived at the right door.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was opened assoon as he knocked and, paying no attention to the woman he had seenlast time who was standing at the doorway, he was about to go straightinto the adjoining room when she said to him "There's no session today".
author: Franz Kafka

text: "What do you mean; no session?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: he asked, unable to believe it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But thewoman persuaded him by opening the door to the next room.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was indeedempty, and looked even more dismal empty than it had the previousSunday.
author: Franz Kafka

text: On the podium stood the table exactly as it had been beforewith a few books laying on it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Can I have a look at those books?
author: Franz Kafka

text: "asked K., not because he was especially curious but so that he would nothave come for nothing.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "No," said the woman as she re-closed the door,"that's not allowed.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Those books belong to the examining judge."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Isee," said K., and nodded, "those books must be law books, and that'show this court does things, not only to try people who are innocent buteven to try them without letting them know what's going on."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I expectyou're right," said the woman, who had not understood exactly what hemeant.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I'd better go away again, then," said K."Should I give a message to the examining judge?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: asked the woman.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Doyou know him, then?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: asked K.  "Of course I know him," said the woman,"my husband is the court usher."
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was only now that K. noticed thatthe room, which before had held nothing but a wash-tub, had been fittedout as a living room.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The woman saw how surprised he was and said,"Yes, we're allowed to live here as we like, only we have to clear theroom out when the court's in session.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He had a list of these cases here in the drawer -here he would tap on one or other of the drawers in his desk - butcould, unfortunately, not show them to K. as they dealt with officialsecrets.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Nonetheless, the great experience he had acquired through allthese cases would, of course, be of benefit to K.  He had, of course,begun work straight away and was nearly ready to submit the firstdocuments.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They would be very important because the first impressionmade by the defence will often determine the whole course of theproceedings.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Unfortunately, though, he would still have to make itclear to K. that the first documents submitted are sometimes not evenread by the court.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They simply put them with the other documents andpoint out that, for the time being, questioning and observing theaccused are much more important than anything written.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If the applicantbecomes insistent, then they add that before they come to any decision,as soon as all the material has been brought together, with due regard,of course, to all the documents, then these first documents to have beensubmitted will also be checked over.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But unfortunately, even this isnot usually true, the first documents submitted are usually mislaid orlost completely, and even if they do keep them right to the end they arehardly read, although the lawyer only knew about this from rumour.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Thisis all very regrettable, but not entirely without its justifications.But K. should not forget that the trial would not be public, if thecourt deems it necessary it can be made public but there is no law thatsays it has to be.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As a result, the accused and his defence don't haveaccess even to the court records, and especially not to the indictment,and that means we generally don't know - or at least not precisely -what the first documents need to be about, which means that if they docontain anything of relevance to the case it's only by a luckycoincidence.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If anything about the individual charges and the reasonsfor them comes out clearly or can be guessed at while the accused isbeing questioned, then it's possible to work out and submit documentsthat really direct the issue and present proof, but not before.Conditions like this, of course, place the defence in a veryunfavourable and difficult position.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But that is what they intend.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Infact, defence is not really allowed under the law, it's only tolerated,and there is even some dispute about whether the relevant parts of thelaw imply even that.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So strictly speaking, there is no such thing as acounsel acknowledged by the court, and anyone who comes before thiscourt as counsel is basically no more than a barrack room lawyer.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Theeffect of all this, of course, is to remove the dignity of the wholeprocedure, the next time K. is in the court offices he might like tohave a look in at the lawyers' room, just so that he's seen it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Hemight well be quite shocked by the people he sees assembled there.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Theroom they've been allocated, with its narrow space and low ceiling, willbe enough to show what contempt the court has for these people.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Theonly light in the room comes through a little window that is so high upthat, if you want to look out of it, you first have to get one of yourcolleagues to support you on his back, and even then the smoke from thechimney just in front of it will go up your nose and make your faceblack.
author: Franz Kafka

text: In the floor of this room - to give yet another example of theconditions there - there is a hole that's been there for more than ayear, it's not so big that a man could fall through, but it is bigenough for your foot to disappear through it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The lawyers' room is onthe second floor of the attic; if your foot does go through it will hangdown into the first floor of the attic underneath it, and right in thecorridor where the litigants are waiting.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It's no exaggeration whenlawyers say that conditions like that are a disgrace.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Complaints to themanagement don't have the slightest effect, but the lawyers are strictlyforbidden to alter anything in the room at their own expense.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But eventreating the lawyers in this way has its reasons.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They want, as far aspossible, to prevent any kind of defence, everything should be made theresponsibility of the accused.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Not a bad point of view, basically, butnothing could be more mistaken than to think from that that lawyers arenot necessary for the accused in this court.
author: Franz Kafka

text: On the contrary, there isno court where they are less needed than here.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This is becauseproceedings are generally kept secret not only from the public but alsofrom the accused.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Only as far as that is possible, of course, but it ispossible to a very large extent.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And the accused doesn't get to see thecourt records either, and it's very difficult to infer what's in thecourt records from what's been said during questioning based on them,especially for the accused who is in a difficult situation and is facedwith every possible worry to distract him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This is when the defencebegins.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Counsel for the defence are not normally allowed to be presentwhile the accused is being questioned, so afterwards, and if possiblestill at the door of the interview room, he has to learn what he canabout it from him and extract whatever he can that might be of use, eventhough what the accused has to report is often very confused.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But thatis not the most important thing, as there's really not a lot that can belearned in this way, although in this, as with anything else, acompetent man will learn more than another.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Nonetheless, the mostimportant thing is the lawyer's personal connections, that's where thereal value of taking counsel lies.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Now K. will most likely have alreadylearned from his own experience that, among its very lowest orders, thecourt organisation does have its imperfections, the court is strictlyclosed to the public, but staff who forget their duty or who take bribesdo, to some extent, show where the gaps are.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This is where most lawyerswill push their way in, this is where bribes are paid and informationextracted, there have even, in earlier times at least, been incidentswhere documents have been stolen.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There's no denying that somesurprisingly favourable results have been attained for the accused inthis way, for a limited time, and these petty advocates then strut toand fro on the basis of them and attract new clients, but for thefurther course of the proceedings it signifies either nothing or nothinggood.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The only things of real value are honest personal contacts,contacts with higher officials, albeit higher officials of the lowergrades, you understand.
author: Franz Kafka

text: That is the only way the progress of the trialcan be influenced, hardly noticeable at first, it's true, but from thenon it becomes more and more visible.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There are, of course, not manylawyers who can do this, and K. has made a very good choice in thismatter.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There were probably no more than one or two who had as manycontacts as Dr. Huld, but they don't bother with the company of thelawyers' room and have nothing to do with it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This means they have allthe less contact with the court officials.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It is not at all necessaryfor Dr. Huld to go to the court, wait in the ante-rooms for theexamining judges to turn up, if they turn up, and try to achievesomething which, according to the judges' mood is usually more apparentthan real and most often not even that.
author: Franz Kafka

text: No, K. has seen for himselfthat the court officials, including some who are quite high up, comeforward without being asked, are glad to give information which is fullyopen or at least easy to understand, they discuss the next stages in theproceedings, in fact in some cases they can be won over and are quitewilling to adopt the other person's point of view.
author: Franz Kafka

text: However, when thishappens, you should never trust them too far, as however firmly they mayhave declared this new point of view in favour of the defendant theymight well go straight back to their offices and write a report for thecourt that says just the opposite, and might well be even harder on thedefendant than the original view, the one they insist they've been fullydissuaded from.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And, of course, there's no way of defending yourselffrom this, something said in private is indeed in private and cannotthen be used in public, it's not something that makes it easy for thedefence to keep those gentlemen's favour.
author: Franz Kafka

text: On the other hand, it's alsotrue that the gentlemen don't become involved with the defence - whichwill of course be done with great expertise - just for philanthropicreasons or in order to be friendly, in some respects it would be truerto say that they, too, have it allocated to them.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This is where thedisadvantages of a court structure that, right from the start,stipulates that all proceedings take place in private, come into force.In normal, mediocre trials its officials have contact with the public,and they're very well equipped for it, but here they don't; normaltrials run their course all by themselves, almost, and just need a nudgehere and there; but when they're faced with cases that are especiallydifficult they're as lost as they often are with ones that are verysimple; they're forced to spend all their time, day and night, withtheir laws, and so they don't have the right feel for humanrelationships, and that's a serious shortcoming in cases like this.That's when they come for advice to the lawyer, with a servant behindthem carrying the documents which normally are kept so secret.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Youcould have seen many gentlemen at this window, gentlemen of whom youwould least expect it, staring out this window in despair on the streetbelow while the lawyer is at his desk studying the documents so that hecan give them good advice.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And at times like that it's also possible tosee how exceptionally seriously these gentlemen take their professionsand how they are thrown into great confusion by difficulties which it'sjust not in their natures to overcome.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But they're not in an easyposition, to regard their positions as easy would be to do them aninjustice.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The different ranks and hierarchies of the court areendless, and even someone who knows his way around them cannot alwaystell what's going to happen.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But even for the junior officials, theproceedings in the courtrooms are usually kept secret, so they arehardly able to see how the cases they work with proceed, court affairsappear in their range of vision often without their knowing where theycome from and they move on further without their learning where they go.So civil servants like this are not able to learn the things you canlearn from studying the successive stages that individual trials gothrough, the final verdict or the reasons for it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They're only allowedto deal with that part of the trial which the law allocates them, andthey usually know less about the results of their work after it's leftthem than the defence does, even though the defence will usually stay incontact with the accused until the trial is nearly at its end, so thatthe court officials can learn many useful things from the defence.Bearing all this in mind, does it still surprise K. that the officialsare irritated and often express themselves about the litigants inunflattering ways - which is an experience shared by everyone.
author: Franz Kafka

text: All theofficials are irritated, even when they appear calm.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This causes manydifficulties for the junior advocates, of course.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There is a story, forinstance, that has very much the ring of truth about it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It goes likethis: One of the older officials, a good and peaceful man, was dealingwith a difficult matter for the court which had become very confused,especially thanks to the contributions from the lawyers.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He had beenstudying it for a day and a night without a break - as these officialsare indeed hard working, no-one works as hard as they do.
author: Franz Kafka

text: When it wasnearly morning, and he had been working for twenty-four hours withprobably very little result, he went to the front entrance, waited therein ambush, and every time a lawyer tried to enter the building he wouldthrow him down the steps.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The lawyers gathered together down in frontof the steps and discussed with each other what they should do; on theone hand they had actually no right to be allowed into the building sothat there was hardly anything that they could legally do to theofficial and, as I've already mentioned, they would have to be carefulnot to set all the officials against them.
author: Franz Kafka

text: On the other hand, any daynot spent in court is a day lost for them and it was a matter of someimportance to force their way inside.
author: Franz Kafka

text: In the end, they agreed that theywould try to tire the old man out.
author: Franz Kafka

text: One lawyer after another was sentout to run up the steps and let himself be thrown down again, offeringwhat resistance he could as long as it was passive resistance, and hiscolleagues would catch him at the bottom of the steps.
author: Franz Kafka

text: That went on forabout an hour until the old gentleman, who was already exhausted fromworking all night, was very tired and went back to his office.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Thosewho were at the bottom of the steps could not believe it at first, sothey sent somebody out to go and look behind the door to see if therereally was no-one there, and only then did they all gather together andprobably didn't even dare to complain, as it's far from being thelawyers' job to introduce any improvements in the court system, or evento want to.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Even the most junior lawyer can understand the relationshipthere to some extent, but one significant point is that almost everydefendant, even very simple people, begins to think of suggestions forimproving the court as soon as his proceedings have begun, many of themoften even spend time and energy on the matter that could be spent farbetter elsewhere.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The only right thing to do is to learn how to dealwith the situation as it is.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Even if it were possible to improve anydetail of it - which is anyway no more than superstitious nonsense - thebest that they could achieve, although doing themselves incalculableharm in the process, is that they will have attracted the specialattention of the officials for any case that comes up in the future, andthe officials are always ready to seek revenge.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Never attract attentionto yourself!
author: Franz Kafka

text: Stay calm, however much it goes against your character!Try to gain some insight into the size of the court organism and how, tosome extent, it remains in a state of suspension, and that even if youalter something in one place you'll draw the ground out from under yourfeet and might fall, whereas if an enormous organism like the court isdisrupted in any one place it finds it easy to provide a substitute foritself somewhere else.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Everything is connected with everything else andwill continue without any change or else, which is quite probable, evenmore closed, more attentive, more strict, more malevolent.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So it's bestto leave the work to the lawyers and not to keep disturbing them.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Itdoesn't do much good to make accusations, especially if you can't makeit clear what they're based on and their full significance, but it mustbe said that K. caused a great deal of harm to his own case by hisbehaviour towards the office director, he was a very influential man butnow he might as well be struck off the list of those who might doanything for K.  If the trial is mentioned, even just in passing,  it'squite obvious that he's ignoring it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: These officials are in many waysjust like children.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Often, something quite harmless - although K.'sbehaviour could unfortunately not be called harmless - will leave themfeeling so offended that they will even stop talking with good friendsof theirs, they turn away when they see them and do everything they canto oppose them.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But then, with no particular reason, surprisinglyenough, some little joke that was only ever attempted because everythingseemed so hopeless will make them laugh and they'll be reconciled.It's both difficult and hard at the same time to deal with them, andthere's hardly any reason for it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It's sometimes quite astonishing thata single, average life is enough to encompass so much that it's at allpossible ever to have any success in one's work here.
author: Franz Kafka

text: On the otherhand, there are also dark moments, such as everyone has, when you thinkyou've achieved nothing at all, when it seems that the only trials tocome to a good end are those that were determined to have a good endfrom the start and would do so without any help, while all the othersare lost despite all the running to and fro, all the effort, all thelittle, apparent successes that gave such joy.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Then you no longer feelvery sure of anything and, if asked about a trial that was doing well byits own nature but which was turned for the worse because you assistedin it, would not even dare deny that.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And even that is a kind of self-confidence, but then it's the only one that's left.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Lawyers areespecially vulnerable to fits of depression of that sort - and they areno more than fits of depression of course - when a case is suddenlytaken out of their hands after they've been conducting it satisfactorilyfor some time.
author: Franz Kafka

text: That's probably the worst that can happen to a lawyer.It's not that the accused takes the case away from him, that hardly everhappens, once a defendant has taken on a certain lawyer he has to staywith him whatever happens.
author: Franz Kafka

text: How could he ever carry on by himself afterhe's taken on help from a lawyer?
author: Franz Kafka

text: No, that just doesn't happen, butwhat does sometimes happen is that the trial takes on a course where thelawyer may not go along with it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Client and trial are both simply takenaway from the lawyer; and then even contact with the court officialswon't help, however good they are, as they don't know anythingthemselves.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The trial will have entered a stage where no more help canbe given, where it's being processed in courts to which no-one has anyaccess, where the defendant cannot even be contacted by his lawyer.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Youcome home one day and find all the documents you've submitted, whichyou've worked hard to create and which you had the best hopes for, lyingon the desk, they've been sent back as they can't be carried through tothe next stage in the trial, they're just worthless scraps of paper.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Itdoesn't mean that the case has been lost, not at all, or at least thereis no decisive reason for supposing so, it's just that you don't knowanything more about the case and won't be told anything of what'shappening.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Well, cases like that are the exceptions, I'm glad to say,and even if K.'s trial is one of them, it's still, for the time being, along way off.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But there was still plenty of opportunity for lawyers toget to work, and K. could be sure they would be made use of.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As he hadsaid, the time for submitting documents was still in the future andthere was no rush to prepare them, it was much more important to startthe initial discussions with the appropriate officials, and they hadalready taken place.
author: Franz Kafka

text: With varying degrees of success, it must be said.It was much better not to give away any details before their time, as inthat way K. could only be influenced unfavourably and his hopes might beraised or he might be made too anxious, better just to say that someindividuals have spoken very favourably and shown themselves verywilling to help, although others have spoken less favourably, but eventhey have not in any way refused to help.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So all in all, the resultsare very encouraging, only you should certainly not draw any particularconclusions as all preliminary proceedings begin in the same way and itwas only the way they developed further that would show what the valueof these preliminary proceedings has been.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Anyway, nothing has beenlost yet, and if we can succeed in getting the office director, despiteeverything, on our side - and several actions have been undertaken tothis end - then everything is a clean wound, as a surgeon would say, andwe can wait for the results with some comfort.
author: Franz Kafka

text: When he started talking on in this way the lawyer was quitetireless.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He went through it all again every time K. went to see him.There was always some progress, but he could never be told what sort ofprogress it was.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The first set of documents to be submitted were beingworked on but still not ready, which usually turned out to be a greatadvantage the next time K. went to see him as the earlier occasion wouldhave been a very bad time to put them in, which they could not then haveknown.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If K., stupefied from all this talking, ever pointed out thateven considering all these difficulties progress was very slow, thelawyer would object that progress was not slow at all, but that theymight have progressed far further if K. had come to him at the righttime.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But he had come to him late and that lateness would bring stillfurther difficulties, and not only where time was concerned.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The onlywelcome interruption during these visits was always when Leni contrivedto bring the lawyer his tea while K. was there.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Then she would standbehind K. - pretending to watch the lawyer as he bent greedily over hiscup, poured the tea in and drank - and secretly let K. hold her hand.There was always complete silence.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The lawyer drank.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. squeezedLeni's hand and Leni would sometimes dare to gently stroke K.'s hair.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Still here, are you?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: the lawyer would ask when he was ready.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Iwanted to take the dishes away," said Leni, they would give each other'shands a final squeeze, the lawyer would wipe his mouth and then starttalking at K. again with renewed energy.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Was the lawyer trying to comfort K. or to confuse him?
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. couldnot tell, but it seemed clear to him that his defence was not in goodhands.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Maybe everything the lawyer said was quite right, even though heobviously wanted to make himself as conspicuous as possible and probablyhad never even taken on a case as important as he said K.'s was.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But itwas still suspicious how he continually mentioned his personal contactswith the civil servants.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Were they to be exploited solely for K.'sbenefit?
author: Franz Kafka

text: The lawyer never forgot to mention that they were dealing onlywith junior officials, which meant officials who were dependent onothers, and the direction taken in each trial could be important fortheir own furtherment.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Could it be that they were making use of thelawyer to turn trials in a certain direction, which would, of course,always be at the cost of the defendant?
author: Franz Kafka

text: It certainly did not mean thatthey would do that in every trial, that was not likely at all, and therewere probably also trials where they gave the lawyer advantages and allthe room he needed to turn it in the direction he wanted, as it wouldalso be to their advantage to keep his reputation intact.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If thatreally was their relationship, how would they direct K.'s trial which,as the lawyer had explained, was especially difficult and thereforeimportant enough to attract great attention from the very first time itcame to court?
author: Franz Kafka

text: There could not be much doubt about what they would do.The first signs of it could already be seen in the fact that the firstdocuments still had not been submitted even though the trial had alreadylasted several months, and that, according to the lawyer, everything wasstill in its initial stages, which was very effective, of course, inmaking the defendant passive and keeping him helpless.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Then he could besuddenly surprised with the verdict, or at least with a notificationthat the hearing had not decided in his favour and the matter would bepassed on to a higher office.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was essential that K. take a hand in it himself.
author: Franz Kafka

text: On winter'smornings such as this, when he was very tired and everything draggeditself lethargically through his head, this belief of his seemedirrefutable.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He no longer felt the contempt for the trial that he hadhad earlier.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If he had been alone in the world it would have been easyfor him to ignore it, although it was also certain that, in that case,the trial would never have arisen in the first place.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But now, hisuncle had already dragged him to see the lawyer, he had to take accountof his family; his job was no longer totally separate from the progressof the trial, he himself had carelessly - with a certain, inexplicablecomplacency - mentioned it to acquaintances and others had learned aboutit in ways he did not know, his relationship with Miss BÃ¼rstner seemedto be in trouble because of it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: In short, he no longer had any choicewhether he would accept the trial or turn it down, he was in the middleof it and had to defend himself.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If he was tired, then that was bad.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But there was no reason to worry too much before he needed to.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Hehad been capable of working himself up to his high position in the bankin a relatively short time and to retain it with respect from everyone,now he simply had to apply some of the talents that had made thatpossible for him to the trial, and there was no doubt that it had toturn out well.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The most important thing, if something was to beachieved, was to reject in advance any idea that he might be in any wayguilty.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There was no guilt.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The trial was nothing but a big piece ofbusiness, just like he had already concluded to the benefit of the bankmany times, a piece of business that concealed many lurking dangerswaiting in ambush for him, as they usually did, and these dangers wouldneed to be defended against.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If that was to be achieved then he mustnot entertain any idea of guilt, whatever he did, he would need to lookafter his own interests as closely as he could.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Seen in this way, therewas no choice but to take his representation away from the lawyer verysoon, at best that very evening.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The lawyer had told him, as he talkedto him, that that was something unheard of and would probably do him agreat deal of harm, but K. could not tolerate any impediment to hisefforts where his trial was concerned, and these impediments wereprobably caused by the lawyer himself.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But once he had shaken off thelawyer the documents would need to be submitted straight away and, ifpossible, he would need to see to it that they were being dealt withevery day.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It would of course not be enough, if that was to be done,for K. to sit in the corridor with his hat under the bench like theothers.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Day after day, he himself, or one of the women or somebody elseon his behalf, would have to run after the officials and force them tosit at their desks and study K.'s documents instead of looking out onthe corridor through the grating.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There could be no let-up in theseefforts, everything would need to be organised and supervised, it wasabout time that the court came up against a defendant who knew how todefend and make use of his rights.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But when K. had the confidence to try and do all this thedifficulty of composing the documents was too much for him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Earlier,just a week or so before, he could only have felt shame at the thoughtof being made to write out such documents himself;  it had never enteredhis head that the task could also be difficult.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He remembered onemorning when, already piled up with work, he suddenly shoved everythingto one side and took a pad of paper on which he sketched out some of histhoughts on how documents of this sort should proceed.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Perhaps he wouldoffer them to that slow-witted lawyer, but just then the door of themanager's office opened and the deputy-director entered the room with aloud laugh.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. was very embarrassed, although the deputy-director, ofcourse, was not laughing at K.'s documents, which he knew nothing about,but at a joke he had just heard about the stock-exchange, a joke whichneeded an illustration if it was to be understood, and now the deputy-director leant over K.'s desk, took his pencil from his hand, and drewthe illustration on the writing pad that K. had intended for his ideasabout his case.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. now had no more thoughts of shame, the documents had to beprepared and submitted.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If, as was very likely, he could find no timeto do it in the office he would have to do it at home at night.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If thenights weren't enough he would have to take a holiday.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Above all, he couldnot stop half way, that was nonsense not only in business but always andeverywhere.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Needless to say, the documents would mean an almost endlessamount of work.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was easy to come to the belief, not only for thoseof an anxious disposition, that it was impossible ever to finish it.This was not because of laziness or deceit, which were the only thingsthat might have hindered the lawyer in preparing it, but because he didnot know what the charge was or even what consequences it might bring,so that he had to remember every tiny action and event from the whole ofhis life, looking at them from all sides and checking and reconsideringthem.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was also a very disheartening job.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It would have been moresuitable as a way of passing the long days after he had retired andbecome senile.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But now, just when K. needed to apply all his thoughtsto his work, when he was still rising and already posed a threat to thedeputy-director, when every hour passed so quickly and he wanted toenjoy the brief evenings and nights as a young man, this was the time hehad to start working out these documents.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Once more, he began to feelresentment.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Almost involuntarily, only to put an end to it, his fingerfelt for the button of the electric bell in the ante-room.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As hepressed it he glanced up to the clock.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was eleven o'clock, twohours, he had spent a great deal of his costly time just dreaming andhis wits were, of course, even more dulled than they had been before.But the time had, nonetheless, not been wasted, he had come to somedecisions that could be of value.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As well as various pieces of mail,the servitors brought two visiting cards from gentlemen who had alreadybeen waiting for K. for some time.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They were actually very importantclients of the bank who should not really have been kept waiting underany circumstances.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Why had they come at such an awkward time, and why,the gentlemen on the other side of the closed door seemed to be asking,was the industrious K. using up the best business time for his privateaffairs?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Tired from what had gone before, and tired in anticipation ofwhat was to follow, K. stood up to receive the first of them.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He was a short, jolly man, a manufacturer who K. knew well.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Heapologised for disturbing K. at some important work, and K., for hispart, apologised for having kept the manufacturer waiting for so long.But even this apology was spoken in such a mechanical way and with suchfalse intonation that the manufacturer would certainly have noticed ifhe had not been fully preoccupied with his business affairs.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Instead,he hurriedly pulled calculations and tables out from all his pockets,spread them out in front of K., explained several items, corrected alittle mistake in the arithmetic that he noticed as he quickly glancedover it all, and reminded K. of a similar piece of business he'dconcluded with him about a year before, mentioning in passing that thistime there was another bank  spending great effort to get his business,and finally stopped speaking in order to learn K.'s opinion on thematter.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And K. had indeed, at first, been closely following what themanufacturer was saying, he too was aware of how important the deal was,but unfortunately it did not last, he soon stopped listening, nodded ateach of the manufacturer's louder exclamations for a short while, buteventually he stopped doing even that and did no more than stare at thebald head bent over the papers, asking himself when the manufacturerwould finally realise that everything he was saying was useless.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Whenhe did stop talking, K. really thought at first that this was so that hewould have the chance to confess that he was incapable of listening.Instead, seeing the anticipation on the manufacturer's face, obviouslyready to counter any objections made, he was sorry to realise that thebusiness discussion had to be continued.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So he bent his head as if he'dbeen given an order and began slowly to move his pencil over the papers,now and then he would stop and stare at one of the figures.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Themanufacturer thought there must be some objection, perhaps his figuresweren't really sound, perhaps they weren't the decisive issue, whateverhe thought, the manufacturer covered the papers with his hand and beganonce again, moving very close to K., to explain what the deal was allabout.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "It is difficult," said K., pursing his lips.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The only thingthat could offer him any guidance were the papers, and the manufacturerhad covered them from his view, so he just sank back against the arm ofthe chair.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Even when the door of the manager's office opened andrevealed not very clearly, as if through a veil, the deputy director, hedid no more than look up weakly.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. thought no more about the matter,he merely watched the immediate effect of the deputy director'sappearance and, for him, the effect was very pleasing;  the manufacturerimmediately jumped up from his seat and hurried over to meet the deputydirector, although K. would have liked to make him ten times livelier ashe feared the deputy director might disappear again.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He need not haveworried, the two gentlemen met each other, shook each other's hand andwent together over to K.'s desk.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The manufacturer said he was sorry tofind the chief clerk so little inclined to do business, pointing to K.who, under the view of the deputy director, had bent back down over thepapers.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As the two men leant over the desk and the manufacturer madesome effort to gain and keep the deputy director's attention, K. felt asif they were much bigger than they really were and that theirnegotiations were about him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Carefully and slowly turning his eyesupwards, he tried to learn what was taking place above him, took one ofthe papers from his desk without looking to see what it was, lay it onthe flat of his hand and raised it slowly up as he rose up to the levelof the two men himself.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He had no particular plan in mind as he didthis, but merely felt this was how he would act if only he had finishedpreparing that great document that was to remove his burden entirely.The deputy director had been paying all his attention to theconversation and did no more than glance at the paper, he did not readwhat was written on it at all as what was important for the chief clerkwas not important for him, he took it from K.'s hand saying, "Thank you,I'm already familiar with everything", and lay it calmly back on thedesk.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. gave him a bitter, sideways look.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But the deputy director didnot notice this at all, or if he did notice it it only raised hisspirits, he frequently laughed out loud, one time he clearly embarrassedthe manufacturer when he raised an objection in a witty way but drew himimmediately back out of his embarrassment by commenting adversely onhimself, and finally invited him into his office where they could bringthe matter to its conclusion.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "It's a very important matter," said themanufacturer.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I understand that completely.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And I'm sure the chiefclerk ..." - even as he said this he was actually speaking only to themanufacturer - "will be very glad to have us take it off his hands.This is something that needs calm consideration.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But he seems to beover-burdened today, there are even some people in the room outsidewho've been waiting there for hours for him."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. still had enoughcontrol of himself to turn away from the deputy director and direct hisfriendly, albeit stiff, smile only at the manufacturer, he made no otherretaliation, bent down slightly and supported himself with both hands onhis desk like a clerk, and watched as the two gentlemen, still talking,took the papers from his desk and disappeared into the manager's office.In the doorway, the manufacturer turned and said he wouldn't make hisfarewell with K. just yet, he would of course let the chief clerk knowabout the success of his discussions but he also had a little somethingto tell him about.
author: Franz Kafka

text: At last, K. was by himself.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It did not enter his head to showanyone else into his office and only became vaguely aware of how nice itwas that the people outside thought he was still negotiating with themanufacturer and, for this reason, he could not let anyone in to seehim, not even the servitor.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He went over to the window, sat down on theledge beside it, held firmly on to the handle and looked down onto thesquare outside.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The snow was still falling, the weather still had notbrightened up at all.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He remained a long time sitting in this way, not knowing what itactually was that made him so anxious, only occasionally did he glance,slightly startled, over his shoulder at the door to the outer roomwhere, mistakenly, he thought he'd heard some noise.
author: Franz Kafka

text: No-one came, andthat made him feel calmer, he went over to the wash stand, rinsed hisface with cold water and, his head somewhat clearer, went back to hisplace by the window.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The decision to take his defence into his ownhands now seemed more of a burden than he had originally assumed.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Allthe while he had left his defence up to the lawyer his trial had hadlittle basic affect on him, he had observed it from afar as somethingthat was scarcely able to reach him directly, when it suited him helooked to see how things stood but he was also able to draw his headback again whenever he wanted.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Now, in contrast, if he was to conducthis defence himself, he would have to devote himself entirely to thecourt - for the time being, at least - success would mean, later on, hiscomplete and conclusive liberation, but if he was to achieve this hewould have to place himself, to start with, in far greater danger thanhe had been in so far.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If he ever felt tempted to doubt this, then hisexperience with the deputy director and the manufacturer that day wouldbe quite enough to convince him of it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: How could he have sat theretotally convinced of the need to do his own defence?
author: Franz Kafka

text: How would it belater?
author: Franz Kafka

text: What would his life be like in the days ahead?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Would he findthe way through it all to a happy conclusion?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Did a carefully workedout defence - and any other sort would have made no sense - did acarefully worked out defence not also mean he would need to shut himselfoff from everything else as much as he could?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Would he survive that?And how was he to succeed in conducting all this at the bank?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Itinvolved much more than just submitting some documents that he couldprobably prepare in a few days' leave, although it would have been greattemerity to ask for time off from the bank just at that time, it was awhole trial and there was no way of seeing how long it might last.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Thiswas an enormous difficulty that had suddenly been thrown into K.'s life!
author: Franz Kafka

text: And was he supposed to be doing the bank's work at a time likethis?
author: Franz Kafka

text: He looked down at his desk.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Was he supposed to let people in tosee him and go into negotiations with them at a time like this?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Whilehis trial trundled on, while the court officials upstairs in the atticroom sat looking at the papers for this trial, should he be worryingabout the business of the bank?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Did this not seem like a kind oftorture, acknowledged by the court, connected with the trial and whichfollowed him around?
author: Franz Kafka

text: And is it likely that anyone in the bank, whenjudging his work, would take any account of his peculiar situation?
author: Franz Kafka

text: No-one and never.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There were those who knew about his trial, although itwas not quite clear who knew about it or how much.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But he hoped rumourshad not reached as far as the deputy director, otherwise he wouldobviously soon find a way of making use of it to harm K., he would showneither comradeship nor humaneness.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And what about the director?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Itwas true that he was well disposed towards K., and as soon as he heardabout the trial he would probably try to do everything he could to makeit easier for him, but he would certainly not devote himself to it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K.at one time had provided the counter-balance to what the deputy directorsaid but the director was now coming more and more under his influence,and the deputy director would also exploit the weakened condition of thedirector to strengthen his own power.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So what could K. hope for?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Maybeconsiderations of this sort weakened his power of resistance, but it wasstill necessary not to deceive oneself and to see everything as clearlyas it could be seen at that moment.
author: Franz Kafka

text: For no particular reason, just to avoiding returning to his deskfor a while, he opened the window.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was difficult to open and he hadto turn the handle with both his hands.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Then, through the whole heightand breadth of the window, the mixture of fog and smoke was drawn intothe room, filling it with a slight smell of burning.
author: Franz Kafka

text: A few flakes ofsnow were blown in with it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "It's a horrible autumn," said themanufacturer, who had come into the room unnoticed after seeing thedeputy director and now stood behind K.  K. nodded and looked uneasilyat the manufacturer's briefcase, from which he would now probably takethe papers and inform K. of the result of his negotiations with thedeputy director.
author: Franz Kafka

text: However, the manufacturer saw where K. was looking,knocked on his briefcase and without opening it said, "You'll be wantingto hear how things turned out.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I've already got the contract in mypocket, almost.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He's a charming man, your deputy director - he's gothis dangers, though."
author: Franz Kafka

text: He laughed as he shook K.'s hand and wanted tomake him laugh with him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But to K., it once more seemed suspicious thatthe manufacturer did not want to show him the papers and saw nothingabout his comments to laugh at.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Chief clerk," said the manufacturer,"I expect the weather's been affecting your mood, has it?
author: Franz Kafka

text: You're lookingso worried today."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Yes," said K., raising his hand and holding thetemple of his head, "headaches, worries in the family."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Quite right,"said the manufacturer, who was always in a hurry and could never listento anyone for very long, "everyone has his cross to bear."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. hadunconsciously made a step towards the door as if wanting to show themanufacturer out, but the manufacturer said, "Chief clerk, there'ssomething else I'd like to mention to you.
