text: I'm very sorry if it'ssomething that'll be a burden to you today of all days but I've been tosee you twice already, lately, and each time I forgot all about it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: IfI delay it any longer it might well lose its point altogether.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Thatwould be a pity, as I think what I've got to say does have some value.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Before K. had had the time to answer, the manufacturer came up close tohim, tapped his knuckle lightly on his chest and said quietly, "You'vegot a trial going on, haven't you?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. stepped back and immediatelyexclaimed, "That's what the deputy director's been telling you!"
author: Franz Kafka

text: "No,no," said the manufacturer, "how would the deputy director know aboutit?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: "And what about you?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: asked K., already more in control ofhimself.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I hear things about the court here and there," said themanufacturer, "and that even applies to what it is that I wanted to tellyou about."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "There are so many people who have connections with thecourt!"
author: Franz Kafka

text: said K. with lowered head, and he led the manufacturer over tohis desk.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They sat down where they had been before, and themanufacturer said, "I'm afraid it's not very much that I've got to tellyou about.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Only, in matters like this, it's best not to overlook thetiniest details.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Besides, I really want to help you in some way,however modest my help might be.
author: Franz Kafka

text: We've been good business partners uptill now, haven't we?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Well then."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. wanted to apologise for hisbehaviour in the conversation earlier that day, but the manufacturerwould tolerate no interruption, shoved his briefcase up high in hisarmpit to show that he was in a hurry, and carried on.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I know aboutyour case through a certain Titorelli.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He's a painter, Titorelli's justhis artistic name, I don't even know what his real name is.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He's beencoming to me in my office for years from time to time, and brings littlepictures with him which I buy more or less just for the sake of charityas he's hardly more than a beggar.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And they're nice pictures, too,moorland landscapes and that sort of thing.
author: Franz Kafka

text: We'd both got used to doingbusiness in this way and it always went smoothly.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Only, one time thesevisits became a bit too frequent, I began to tell him off for it, westarted talking and I became interested how it was that he could earn aliving just by painting, and then I learned to my amazement that hismain source of income was painting portraits.
author: Franz Kafka

text: 'I work for the court,'he said, 'what court?'
author: Franz Kafka

text: said I.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And that's when he told me about thecourt.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I'm sure you can imagine how amazed I was at being told allthis.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Ever since then I learn something new about the court every timehe comes to visit, and so little by little I get to understand somethingof how it works.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Anyway, Titorelli talks a lot and I often have to pushhim away, not only because he's bound to be lying but also, most of all,because a businessman like me who's already close to breaking pointunder the weight of his own business worries can't pay too muchattention to other people's.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But all that's just by the by.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Perhaps -this is what I've been thinking - perhaps Titorelli might be able tohelp you in some small way, he knows lots of judges and even if he can'thave much influence himself he can give you some advice about how to getsome influential people on your side.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And even if this advice doesn'tturn out to make all the difference I still think it'll be veryimportant once you've got it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: You're nearly a lawyer yourself.
author: Franz Kafka

text: That'swhat I always say, Mr. K. the chief clerk is nearly a lawyer.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Oh I'msure this trial of yours will turn out all right.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So do you want to goand see Titorelli, then?
author: Franz Kafka

text: If I ask him to he'll certainly do everythinghe possibly can.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I really do think you ought to go.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It needn't betoday, of course, just some time, when you get the chance.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And anyway -I want to tell you this too -  you don't actually have to go and seeTitorelli, this advice from me doesn't place you under any obligation atall.
author: Franz Kafka

text: No, if you think you can get by without Titorelli it'll certainlybe better to leave him completely out of it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Maybe you've already got aclear idea of what you're doing and Titorelli could upset your plans.No, if that's the case then of course you shouldn't go there under anycircumstances!
author: Franz Kafka

text: And it certainly won't be easy to take advice from a ladlike that.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Still, it's up to you.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Here's the letter of recommendationand here's the address."
author: Franz Kafka

text: Disappointed, K. took the letter and put it in his pocket.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Evenat best, the advantage he might derive from this recommendation wasincomparably smaller than the damage that lay in the fact of themanufacturer knowing about his trial, and that the painter was spreadingthe news about.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was all he could manage to give the manufacturer, whowas already on his way to the door, a few words of thanks.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I'll gothere," he said as he took his leave of the manufacturer at the door,"or, as I'm very busy at present, I'll write to him, perhaps he wouldlike to come to me in my office some time."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I was sure you'd find thebest solution," said the manufacturer.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Although I had thought you'dprefer to avoid inviting people like this Titorelli to the bank andtalking about the trial here.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And it's not always a good idea to sendletters to people like Titorelli, you don't know what might happen tothem.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But you're bound to have thought everything through and you knowwhat you can and can't do."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. nodded and accompanied the manufactureron through the ante-room.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But despite seeming calm on the outside hewas actually very shocked; he had told the manufacturer he would writeto Titorelli only to show him in some way that he valued hisrecommendations and would consider the opportunity to speak withTitorelli without delay, but if he had thought Titorelli could offer anyworthwhile assistance he would not have delayed.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But it was only themanufacturer's comment that made K. realise what dangers that could leadto.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Was he really able to rely on his own understanding so little?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Ifit was possible that he might invite a questionable character into thebank with a clear letter, and ask advice from him about his trial,separated from the deputy director by no more than a door, was it notpossible or even very likely that there were also other dangers he hadfailed to see or that he was even running towards?
author: Franz Kafka

text: There was not alwayssomeone beside him to warn him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And just now, just when he would haveto act with all the strength he could muster, now a number of doubts ofa sort he had never before known had presented themselves and affectedhis own vigilance!
author: Franz Kafka

text: The difficulties he had been feeling in carrying outhis office work; were they now going to affect the trial too?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Now, atleast, he found himself quite unable to understand how he could haveintended to write to Titorelli and invite him into the bank.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He shook his head at the thought of it once more as the servitorcame up beside him and drew his attention to the three gentlemen whowere waiting on a bench in the ante-room.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They had already been waitingto see K. for a long time.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Now that the servitor was speaking with K.they had stood up and each of them wanted to make use of the opportunityto see K. before the others.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It had been negligent of the bank to letthem waste their time here in the waiting room, but none of them wantedto draw attention to this.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Mr. K., ..." one of them was saying, but K.had told the servitor to fetch his winter coat and said to the three ofthem, as the servitor helped him to put it on, "Please forgive me,gentlemen, I'm afraid I have no time to see you at present.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Please doforgive me but I have some urgent business to settle and have to leavestraight away.
author: Franz Kafka

text: You've already seen yourselves how long I've beendelayed.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Would you be so kind as to come back tomorrow or some time?Or perhaps we could settle your affairs by telephone?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Or perhaps youwould like to tell me now, briefly, what it's about and I can then giveyou a full answer in writing.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Whatever, the best thing will be for youto come here again."
author: Franz Kafka

text: The gentlemen now saw that their wait had beentotally pointless, and these suggestions of K.'s left them so astoundedthat they looked at each other without a word.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "That's agreed then, isit?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: asked K., who had turned toward the servitor bringing him his hat.Through the open door of K.'s office they could see that the snowfalloutside had become much heavier.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So K. turned the collar of his coat upand buttoned it up high under his chin.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Just then the deputy directorcame out of the adjoining room, smiled as he saw K. negotiating with thegentlemen in his winter coat, and asked, "Are you about to go out?
author: Franz Kafka

text: ""Yes," said K., standing more upright, "I have to go out on somebusiness."
author: Franz Kafka

text: But the deputy director had already turned towards thegentlemen.

author: Franz Kafka

text: "We've already come toan understanding," said K.  But now the gentlemen could be held back nolonger, they surrounded K. and explained that they would not have beenwaiting for hours if it had not been about something important that hadto be discussed now, at length and in private.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The deputy directorlistened to them for a short while, he also looked at K. as he held hishat in his hand cleaning the dust off it here and there, and then hesaid, "Gentlemen, there is a very simple way to solve this.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If youwould prefer it, I'll be very glad to take over these negotiationsinstead of the chief clerk.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Your business does, of course, need to bediscussed without delay.
author: Franz Kafka

text: We are businessmen like yourselves and knowthe value of a businessman's time.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Would you like to come this way?
author: Franz Kafka

text: "And he opened the door leading to the ante-room of his own office.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The deputy director seemed very good at appropriating everythingthat K. was now forced to give up!
author: Franz Kafka

text: But was K. not giving up more thanhe absolutely had to?
author: Franz Kafka

text: By running off to some unknown painter, with, ashe had to admit, very little hope of any vague benefit, his renown wassuffering damage that could not be repaired.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It would probably be muchbetter to take off his winter coat again and, at the very least, try towin back the two gentlemen who were certainly still waiting in the nextroom.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If K. had not then glimpsed the deputy director in his office,looking for something from his bookshelves as if they were his own, hewould probably even have made the attempt.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As K., somewhat agitated,approached the door the deputy director called out, "Oh, you've stillnot left!"
author: Franz Kafka

text: He turned his face toward him - its many deep folds seemedto show strength rather than age - and immediately began once more tosearch.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I'm looking for a copy of a contract," he said, "which thisgentleman  insists you must have.

text: Could you help me look for it, do youthink?"

text: K. made a step forward, but the deputy director said, "thankyou, I've already found it," and with a big package of papers, whichcertainly must have included many more documents than just the copy ofthe contract, he turned and went back into his own office.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I can't deal with him right now," K. said to himself, "but oncemy personal difficulties have been settled, then he'll certainly be thefirst to get the effect of it, and he certainly won't like it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Slightly calmed by these thoughts, K. gave the servitor, who had alreadylong been holding the door to the corridor open for him, the task oftelling the director, when he was able, that K. was going out of thebank on a business matter.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As he left the bank he felt almost happy atthe thought of being able to devote more of himself to his own businessfor a while.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He went straight to the painter, who lived in an outlying part oftown which was very near to the court offices, although this area waseven poorer, the houses were darker, the streets were full of dirt thatslowly blew about over the half-melted snow.
author: Franz Kafka

text: In the great gateway tothe building where the painter lived only one of the two doors was open,a hole had been broken open in the wall by the other door, and as K.approached it a repulsive, yellow, steaming liquid shot out causing somerats to scurry away into the nearby canal.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Down by the staircase therewas a small child lying on its belly crying, but it could hardly beheard because of the noise from a metal-workshop on the other side ofthe entrance hall, drowning out any other sound.

text: The door to theworkshop was open, three workers stood in a circle around some piece ofwork that they were beating with hammers.
author: Franz Kafka

text: A large tin plate hung on thewall, casting a pale light that pushed its way in between two of theworkers, lighting up their faces and their work-aprons.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. did no morethan glance at any of these things, he wanted to get things over withhere as soon as possible, to exchange just a few words to find out howthings stood with the painter and go straight back to the bank.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Even ifhe had just some tiny success here it would still have a good effect onhis work at the bank for that day.

text: On the third floor he had to slowdown his pace, he was quite out of breath - the steps, just like theheight of each floor, were much higher than they needed to be and he'dbeen told that the painter lived right up in the attic.

text: The air wasalso quite oppressive, there was no proper stairwell and the narrowsteps were closed in by walls on both sides with no more than a small,high window here and there.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Just as K. paused for a while some younggirls ran out of one of the flats and rushed higher up the stairs,laughing.

text: K. followed them slowly, caught up with one of the girls whohad stumbled and been left behind by the others, and asked her as theywent up side by side, "Is there a painter, Titorelli, who lives here?
author: Franz Kafka

text: "The girl, hardly thirteen years old and somewhat hunchbacked, jabbed himwith her elbow and looked at him sideways.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Her youth and her bodilydefects had done nothing to stop her being already quite depraved.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Shedid not smile once, but looked at K. earnestly, with sharp, acquisitiveeyes.

text: "Paint your portrait?"

author: Franz Kafka

text: Sothere's no point in it from this side either.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They could replace thewhole court with a single hangman."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "You shouldn't generalise," saidthe painter, dissatisfied, "I've only been talking about my ownexperience."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Well that's enough," said K., "or have you heard of anyacquittals that happened earlier?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: "They say there have been someacquittals earlier," the painter answered, "but it's very hard to besure about it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The courts don't make their final conclusions public,not even the judges are allowed to know about them, so that all we knowabout these earlier cases are just legends.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But most of them didinvolve absolute acquittals, you can believe that, but they can't beproved.
author: Franz Kafka

text: On the other hand, you shouldn't forget all about them either,I'm sure there is some truth to them, and they are very beautiful, I'vepainted a few pictures myself depicting these legends."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "My assessmentwill not be altered by mere legends," said K.  "I don't suppose it'spossible to cite these legends in court, is it?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: The painter laughed.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "No, you can't cite them in court," he said.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Then there's no point intalking about them," said K., he wanted, for the time being, to acceptanything the painter told him, even if he thought it unlikely orcontradicted what he had been told by others.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He did not now have thetime to examine the truth of everything the painter said or even todisprove it, he would have achieved as much as he could if the painterwould help him in any way even if his help would not be decisive.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As aresult, he said, "So let's pay no more attention to absolute acquittal,but you mentioned two other possibilities."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Apparent acquittal anddeferment.
author: Franz Kafka

text: They're the only possibilities," said the painter.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Butbefore we talk about them, would you not like to take your coat off?You must be hot."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Yes," said K., who until then had paid attention tonothing but the painter's explanations, but now that he had had the heatpointed out to him his brow began to sweat heavily.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "It's almostunbearable."
author: Franz Kafka

text: The painter nodded as if he understood K.'s discomfortvery well.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Could we not open the window?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: asked K.  "No," said thepainter.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "It's only a fixed pane of glass, it can't be opened."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. nowrealised that all this time he had been hoping the painter wouldsuddenly go over to the window and pull it open.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He had preparedhimself even for the fog that he would breathe in through his openmouth.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The thought that here he was entirely cut off from the air madehim feel dizzy.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He tapped lightly on the bedspread beside him and, witha weak voice, said, "That is very inconvenient and unhealthy."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Oh no,"said the painter in defence of his window, "as it can't be opened thisroom retains the heat better than if the window were double glazed, eventhough it's only a single pane.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There's not much need to air the roomas there's so much ventilation through the gaps in the wood, but when Ido want to I can open one of my doors, or even both of them."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. wasslightly consoled by this explanation and looked around to see where thesecond door was.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The painter saw him do so and said, "It's behind you,I had to hide it behind the bed."
author: Franz Kafka

text: Only then was K. able to see thelittle door in the wall.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "It's really much too small for a studiohere," said the painter, as if he wanted to anticipate an objection K.would make.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I had to arrange things as well as I could.
author: Franz Kafka

text: That'sobviously a very bad place for the bed, in front of the door.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Forinstance when the judge I'm painting at present comes he always comesthrough the door by the bed, and I've even given him a key to this doorso that he can wait for me here in the studio when I'm not home.Although nowadays he usually comes early in the morning when I'm stillasleep.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And of course, it always wakes me up when I hear the dooropened beside the bed, however fast asleep I am.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If you could hear theway I curse him as he climbs over my bed in the morning you'd lose allrespect for judges.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I suppose I could take the key away from him butthat'd only make things worse.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It only takes a tiny effort to break anyof the doors here off their hinges."
author: Franz Kafka

text: All the time the painter wasspeaking, K. was considering whether he should take off his coat, but hefinally realised that, if he didn't do so, he would be quite unable tostay here any longer, so he took off his frock coat and lay it on hisknee so that he could put it back on again as soon as the conversationwas over.
author: Franz Kafka

text: He had hardly done this when one of the girls called out,"Now he's taken his coat off!"
author: Franz Kafka

text: and they could all be heard pressingaround the gaps in the planks to see the spectacle for themselves.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Thegirls think I'm going to paint your portrait," said the painter, "andthat's why you're taking your coat off."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "I see," said K., onlyslightly amused by this, as he felt little better than he had beforeeven though he now sat in his shirtsleeves.
author: Franz Kafka

text: With some irritation heasked, "What did you say the two other possibilities were?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: He hadalready forgotten the terms used.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Apparent acquittal and deferment,"said the painter.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "It's up to you which one you choose.
author: Franz Kafka

text: You can geteither of them if I help you, but it'll take some effort of course, thedifference between them is that apparent acquittal needs concentratedeffort for a while and that deferment takes much less effort but it hasto be sustained.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Now then, apparent acquittal.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If that's what you wantI'll write down an assertion of your innocence on a piece of paper.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Thetext for an assertion of this sort was passed down to me from my fatherand it's quite unassailable.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I take this assertion round to the judgesI know.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So I'll start off with the one I'm currently painting, and putthe assertion to him when he comes for his sitting this evening.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I'lllay the assertion in front of him, explain that you're innocent and givehim my personal guarantee of it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And that's not just a superficialguarantee, it's a real one and it's binding."
author: Franz Kafka

text: The painter's eyes seemedto show some reproach of K. for wanting to impose that sort ofresponsibility on him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "That would be very kind of you", said K.  "Andwould the judge then believe you and nonetheless not pass an absoluteacquittal?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: "It's like I just said," answered the painter.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Andanyway, it's not entirely sure that all the judges would believe me,many of them, for instance, might want me to bring you to see thempersonally.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So then you'd have to come along too.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But at least then,if that happens, the matter is half way won, especially as I'd teach youin advance exactly how you'd need to act with the judge concerned, ofcourse.
author: Franz Kafka

text: What also happens, though, is that there are some judges who'llturn me down in advance, and that's worse.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I'll certainly make severalattempts, but still, we'll have to forget about them, but at least wecan afford to do that as no one judge can pass the decisive verdict.Then when I've got enough judges' signatures on this document I take itto the judge who's concerned with your case.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I might even have hissignature already, in which case things develop a bit quicker than theywould do otherwise.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But there aren't usually many hold ups from thenon, and that's the time that the defendant can feel most confident.It's odd, but true, that people feel more confidence in this time thanthey do after they've been acquitted.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There's no particular exertionneeded now.
author: Franz Kafka

text: When he has the document asserting the defendant'sinnocence, guaranteed by a number of other judges, the judge can acquityou without any worries, and although there are still severalformalities to be gone through there's no doubt that that's what he'lldo as a favour to me and several other acquaintances.
author: Franz Kafka

text: You, however,walk out the court and you're free."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "So, then I'll be free," said K.,hesitantly.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "That's right," said the painter, "but only apparently freeor, to put it a better way, temporarily free, as the most junior judges,the ones I know, they don't have the right to give the final acquittal.Only the highest judge can do that, in the court that's quite out of reachfor you, for me and for all of us.
author: Franz Kafka

text: We don't know how things look thereand, incidentally, we don't want to know.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The right to acquit peopleis a major privilege and our judges don't have it, but they do have theright to free people from the indictment.
author: Franz Kafka

text: That's to say, if they'refreed in this way then for the time being the charge is withdrawn butit's still hanging over their heads and it only takes an order fromhigher up to bring it back into force.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And as I'm in such good contactwith the court I can also tell you how the difference between absoluteand apparent acquittal is described, just in a superficial way, in thedirectives to the court offices.
author: Franz Kafka

text: If there's an absolute acquittal allproceedings should stop, everything disappears from the process, notjust the indictment but the trial and even the acquittal disappears,everything just disappears.
author: Franz Kafka

text: With an apparent acquittal it's different.When that happens, nothing has changed except that the case for yourinnocence, for your acquittal and the grounds for the acquittal havebeen made stronger.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Apart from that, proceedings go on as before, thecourt offices continue their business and the case gets passed to highercourts, gets passed back down to the lower courts and so on, backwardsand forwards, sometimes faster, sometimes slower, to and fro.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It'simpossible to know exactly what's happening while this is going on.Seen from outside it can sometimes seem that everything has been longsince forgotten, the documents have been lost and the acquittal iscomplete.
author: Franz Kafka

text: No-one familiar with the court would believe it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Nodocuments ever get lost, the court forgets nothing.
author: Franz Kafka

text: One day - no-oneexpects it - some judge or other picks up the documents and looks moreclosely at them, he notices that this particular case is still active,and orders the defendant's immediate arrest.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I've been talking here asif there's a long delay between apparent acquittal and re-arrest, thatis quite possible and I do know of cases like that, but it's just aslikely that the defendant goes home after he's been acquitted and findssomebody there waiting to re-arrest him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Then, of course, his life as afree man is at an end."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "And does the trial start over again?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: askedK., finding it hard to believe.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "The trial will always start overagain," said the painter, "but there is, once again as before, thepossibility of getting an apparent acquittal.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Once again, the accusedhas to muster all his strength and mustn't give up."
author: Franz Kafka

text: The painter saidthat last phrase possibly as a result of the impression that K., whoseshoulders had dropped somewhat, gave on him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "But to get a secondacquittal," asked K., as if in anticipation of further revelations bythe painter, "is that not harder to get than the first time?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: "As faras that's concerned," answered the painter, "there's nothing you can sayfor certain.
author: Franz Kafka

text: You mean, do you, that the second arrest would have anadverse influence on the judge and the verdict he passes on thedefendant?
author: Franz Kafka

text: That's not how it happens.
author: Franz Kafka

text: When the acquittal is passed thejudges are already aware that re-arrest is likely.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So when it happensit has hardly any effect.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But there are countless other reasons why thejudges' mood and their legal acumen in the case can be altered, andefforts to obtain the second acquittal must therefore be suited to thenew conditions, and generally just as vigorous as the first."
author: Franz Kafka

text: "But thissecond acquittal will once again not be final," said K., shaking hishead.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Of course not," said the painter, "the second acquittal isfollowed by the third arrest, the third acquittal by the fourth arrestand so on.
author: Franz Kafka

text: That's what is meant by the term apparent acquittal."
author: Franz Kafka

text: K.was silent.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "You clearly don't think an apparent acquittal offers muchadvantage," said the painter, "perhaps deferment would suit you better.Would you like me to explain what deferment is about?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. nodded.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Thepainter had leant back and spread himself out in his chair, hisnightshirt was wide open, he had pushed his hand inside and was strokinghis breast and his sides.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Deferment," said the painter, lookingvaguely in front of himself for a while as if trying to find a perfectlyappropriate explanation, "deferment consists of keeping proceedingspermanently in their earliest stages.
author: Franz Kafka

text: To do that, the accused and thosehelping him need to keep in continuous personal contact with the court,especially those helping him.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I repeat, this doesn't require so mucheffort as getting an apparent acquittal, but it probably requires a lotmore attention.
author: Franz Kafka

text: You must never let the trial out of your sight, youhave to go and see the appropriate judge at regular intervals as well aswhen something in particular comes up and, whatever you do, you have totry and remain friendly with him; if you don't know the judge personallyyou have to influence him through the judges you do know, and you haveto do it without giving up on the direct discussions.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As long as youdon't fail to do any of these things you can be reasonably sure thetrial won't get past its first stages.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The trial doesn't stop, but thedefendant is almost as certain of avoiding conviction as if he'd beenacquitted.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Compared with an apparent acquittal, deferment has theadvantage that the defendant's future is less uncertain, he's safe fromthe shock of being suddenly re-arrested and doesn't need to fear theexertions and stress involved in getting an apparent acquittal just wheneverything else in his life would make it most difficult.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Defermentdoes have certain disadvantages of its own though, too, and theyshouldn't be under-estimated.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I don't mean by this that the defendantis never free, he's never free in the proper sense of the word with anapparent acquittal either.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There's another disadvantage.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Proceedingscan't be prevented from moving forward unless there are some at leastostensible reasons given.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So something needs to seem to be happeningwhen looked at from the outside.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This means that from time to timevarious injunctions have to be obeyed, the accused has to be questioned,investigations have to take place and so on.
author: Franz Kafka

text: The trial's beenartificially constrained inside a tiny circle, and it has to becontinuously spun round within it.
author: Franz Kafka

text: And that, of course, brings with itcertain unpleasantnesses for the accused, although you shouldn't imaginethey're all that bad.
author: Franz Kafka

text: All of this is just for show, the interrogations,for instance, they're only very short, if you ever don't have the timeor don't feel like going to them you can offer an excuse, with somejudges you can even arrange the injunctions together a long time inadvance, in essence all it means is that, as the accused, you have toreport to the judge from time to time."
author: Franz Kafka

text: Even while the painter wasspeaking those last words K. had laid his coat over his arm and hadstood up.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Immediately, from outside the door, there was a cry of  'He'sstanding up now!'.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Are you leaving already?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: asked the painter, whohad also stood up.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "It must be the air that's driving you out.
author: Franz Kafka

text: I'mvery sorry about that.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There's still a lot I need to tell you.
author: Franz Kafka

author: Franz Kafka

text: ""Oh yes," said K., whose head was aching from the effort of listening.Despite this affirmation the painter summed it all up once more, as ifhe wanted to give K. something to console him on his way home.

text: The painter still hadto interpret K.'s mood in some way, so he said, "I expect you'vedeliberately avoided deciding between my suggestions yet.

author: Franz Kafka

text: From under the bed, thepainter withdrew a pile of unframed paintings.

author: Franz Kafka

author: Franz Kafka

text: In the background there was a multi-coloured sunset.

text: "That'snice," said K.  "I'll buy it."
author: Franz Kafka

text: ""We can talk about that next time," said the painter.

text: A lot of people don't like that sort of picture becausethey're too gloomy, but there are others, and you're one of them, wholove gloomy themes."
author: Franz Kafka

text: But K. was not in the mood to hear about theprofessional experiences of this painter cum beggar.

text: "Wrap them allup!"
author: Franz Kafka

text: "There's no need forthat," said the painter.

text: And, at last, he leant over the bed and unlocked thedoor.

author: Franz Kafka

text: Even without thisinvitation, K. had shown no compunction in already placing his foot inthe middle of the bed covers, then he looked out through the open doorand drew his foot back again.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "What is that?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: he asked the painter.

text: "What are you so surprised at?"
author: Franz Kafka

text: he asked, surprised in his turn.
author: Franz Kafka

text: "Thoseare court offices.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Didn't you know there are court offices here?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Thereare court offices in almost every attic, why should this building be anydifferent?
author: Franz Kafka

text: Even my studio is actually one of the court offices but thecourt put it at my disposal."
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was not so much finding court officeseven here that shocked K., he was mainly shocked at himself, at his ownnaÃ¯vety in court matters.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It seemed to him that one of the most basicrules governing how a defendant should behave was always to be prepared,never allow surprises, never to look, unsuspecting, to the right whenthe judge stood beside him to his left - and this was the very basicrule that he was continually violating.
author: Franz Kafka

text: A long corridor extended infront of him, air blew in from it which, compared with the air in thestudio, was refreshing.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There were benches set along each side of thecorridor just as in the waiting area for the office he went to himself.There seemed to be precise rules governing how offices should beequipped.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There did not seem to be many people visiting the officesthat day.
author: Franz Kafka

text: There was a man there, half sitting, half laying, his facewas buried in his arm on the bench and he seemed to be sleeping; anotherman was standing in the half-dark at the end of the corridor.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. nowclimbed over the bed, the painter followed him with the pictures.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Theysoon came across a servant of the court - K. was now able to recogniseall the servants of the court from the gold buttons they wore on theircivilian clothes below the normal buttons - and the painter instructedhim to go with K. carrying the pictures.
author: Franz Kafka

text: K. staggered more than hewalked, his handkerchief pressed over his mouth.

text: They had nearlyreached the exit when the girls stormed in on them, so K. had not beenable to avoid them.

author: Franz Kafka

text: As a servant, the servant of the court was goingto sit on the coach-box.

text: It wasalready well into the afternoon when K. arrived in front of the bank.He would have liked to leave the pictures in the cab but feared theremight be some occasion when he would have to let the painter see hestill had them.
author: Franz Kafka

text: So he had the pictures taken to his office and lockedthem in the lowest drawer of his desk so that he could at least keepthem safe from the deputy director's view for the next few days.Chapter Eight Block, the businessman  - Dismissing the lawyer        K. had at last made the decision to withdraw his defence from thelawyer.

text: It was impossible to remove his doubts as to whether this wasthe right decision, but this was outweighed by his belief in itsnecessity.
author: Franz Kafka

text: This decision, on the day he intended to go to see thelawyer, took a lot of the strength he needed for his work, he workedexceptionally slowly, he had to remain in his office a long time, and itwas already past ten o'clock when he finally stood in front of thelawyer's front door.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Even before he rang he considered whether it mightnot be better to give the lawyer notice by letter or telephone, apersonal conversation would certainly be very difficult.
author: Franz Kafka

text: Nonetheless,K.

text: did not actually want to do without it, if he gave notice by anyother means it would be received in silence or with a few formulatedwords, and unless Leni could discover anything K. would never learn howthe lawyer had taken his dismissal and what its consequences might be,in the lawyer's not unimportant opinion.
author: Franz Kafka

text: But sitting in front of himand taken by surprise by his dismissal, K. would be able easily to infereverything he wanted from the lawyer's face and behaviour, even if hecould not be induced to say very much.
author: Franz Kafka

text: It was not even out of thequestion that K. might, after all, be persuaded that it would be best toleave his defence to the lawyer and withdraw his dismissal.
author: Franz Kafka

text: As usual, there was at first no response to K.'s ring at the door.

text: "Leni could be a bit quicker," thought K.  But he could at least be gladthere was nobody else interfering as usually happened, be it the man inhis nightshirt or anyone else who might bother him.

text: As K. pressed onthe button for the second time he looked back at the other door, butthis time it, too, remained closed.
author: Franz Kafka

text: At last, two eyes appeared at thespy-hatch in the lawyer's door, although they weren't Leni's eyes.Someone unlocked the door, but kept himself pressed against it as hecalled back inside, "It's him!
